meanings.definition: To cause to have a bias; influence in a particular direction.
meanings.sent1: She was biassing the results of the experiment to favor her hypothesis.
meanings.sent2: The news article was biassing the readers towards a specific political view.
meanings.sent3: The magician was biassing the audience's perception with his clever tricks.
meanings.sent4: His loud voice was biassing the outcome of the meeting, drowning out other opinions.
meanings.sent5: The bright colors in the painting were biassing the viewer's emotions, making them feel cheerful.

meanings.definition: To give a particular bias to; prejudice.
meanings.sent1: The teacher was biassing the students by only praising one group's work.
meanings.sent2: Her negative comments were biassing the team against trying new ideas.
meanings.sent3: The cat was biassing the dog's opinion by stealing its favorite toy.
meanings.sent4: The storm clouds were biassing the sky, making it look ominous and threatening.
meanings.sent5: The strong scent of flowers was biassing the room, creating a pleasant atmosphere.

meanings.sent1: The biased judge was biassing the trial by favoring one side.
meanings.sent2: The media was biassing the public's perception by only showing one side of the story.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous elf was biassing the game by secretly moving the pieces.
meanings.sent4: The bright spotlight was biassing the stage, making it hard to see the actors clearly.
meanings.sent5: The strong wind was biassing the tree, causing it to lean to one side.
